summary: This is an email from attorney Aida Leisenring to a prosecutor (likely named Jason) regarding follow-up discovery requests related to the July 23 incident involving Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. The attorney requests video surveillance, photographs/video of cell 124, and access to the orange rope, seeking the prosecution's position on these requests.

persons.name: Aida Leisenring
persons.context: Attorney from Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco LLP sending follow-up discovery requests regarding the July 23 incident (Epstein's death) to a prosecutor.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney at Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco LLP, copied on the email regarding discovery in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jason
persons.context: Prosecutor (likely from the U.S. Attorney's Office) who met with defense attorneys about sensitive disclosure materials and is being asked to follow up on discovery requests related to the July 23 incident.

connections.description: Attorney Leisenring is making discovery requests to prosecutor Jason regarding the investigation into Epstein's death.
Both are attorneys at the same law firm, Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco LLP, working on the Epstein case.

events.title: July 23 Incident (Epstein's Death)
events.description: The incident referenced is the death of Jeffrey Epstein in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Meeting to Review Sensitive Disclosure Materials
events.description: Defense attorneys met with prosecutors in their office to review sensitive disclosure materials related to the Epstein case.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (implied location of cell 124 and July 23 incident)
666 Old Country Road, Ste 700 Garden City, NY 11530 (Law firm address)
keyFacts: Defense attorneys are seeking video surveillance from the hallway near the tier where Epstein was held, related to the July 23 incident (his death).
Defense attorneys are requesting any photographs or video recording of cell 124 taken shortly after the incident.
Defense attorneys want to view the 'orange rope' in person if it was preserved, indicating it is potential evidence.
The email confirms ongoing discovery and investigation into the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody.
